question:
The PARAM 8000 supercomputer was released in which year?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 15/03/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• PARAM 8000 was India's first supercomputer, developed by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC).
  • It was launched in 1991, marking a major technological milestone for India in the field of high-performance computing.
  • The development was initiated in response to the denial of supercomputing technology by foreign countries.

Additional Information:

  • PARAM stands for "Parallel Machine".
  • It was a significant achievement because India built its own supercomputer indigenously.
  • PARAM 8000 had a performance of 1 Gigaflop, which was a huge milestone at that time.

question:
What was India’s first supercomputer called?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• India’s first supercomputer was called PARAM 8000.
  • It was developed by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC) in 1991.
  • The name PARAM stands for “Parallel Machine”, reflecting its parallel processing architecture.

Additional Information:

  • PARAM 8000 was a landmark achievement, as it was developed indigenously after foreign countries denied supercomputing technology to India.
  • It had a performance capability of 1 Gigaflop, making India one of the few nations with supercomputing capability at that time.
  • Other options like SAGA 220 and PARAM 6000 were developed later, and ENIAC was the world’s first electronic computer (not Indian).

question:
Which of the following is the first generation computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 11/03/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is SEAC (Standards Eastern Automatic Computer).
  • SEAC was one of the first generation computers, built in 1950 using vacuum tubes, which is the defining feature of first-generation computers.
  • First-generation computers operated from the 1940s to the mid-1950s and used machine language (binary) for programming.

Additional Information:

  • SEAC was developed by the U.S. National Bureau of Standards and was among the earliest fully operational stored-program computers.
  • ABACUS is not a computer; it is an ancient manual calculating device, not part of any computer generation.
  • ATLAS and STAR 100 were developed much later and belong to later generations of computers (third or fourth).

question:
Who among the following is the Originator of binary logic and arithmetic in Computer programming?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 12/03/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is Claude Shannon.
  • Claude Shannon is widely regarded as the originator of binary logic and arithmetic in computer programming.
  • In his 1937 master's thesis, Shannon showed how Boolean algebra could be used to simplify and design digital circuits — this laid the foundation of digital computing.

Additional Information:

  • Claude Shannon is also known as the father of Information Theory.
  • His work demonstrated how binary numbers (0 and 1) could represent logical operations, forming the basis of all modern digital systems.
  • The other options are:
    • Noam Chomsky – known for formal grammar and linguistics.
    • Leslie Lamport – known for distributed systems and LaTeX.
    • John Backus – developed FORTRAN, one of the earliest high-level programming languages.

question:
What is the full form of ATM?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 09/02/2021 (Shift-II)

RRB NTPC Stage-I 18/04/2016 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct full form of ATM is Automated Teller Machine.
  • An ATM is an electronic banking machine that allows customers to perform basic financial transactions such as withdrawing cash, checking balance, and transferring funds, without the need for a human teller.
  • It is widely used around the world and operates using a debit/credit card and a PIN (Personal Identification Number).

Additional Information:

  • The first ATM was installed in 1967 in London by Barclays Bank.
  • ATMs can be classified as onsite (at the bank premises) or offsite (at other locations like malls or petrol pumps).
  • ATMs help in reducing workload on bank staff and provide 24x7 access to banking services.

question:
In which year did Apple launch the monochrome logo which is using the present time?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 30/04/2016 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Apple launched its monochrome (single-colour) logo in the year 1998.
  • This new design was introduced under the leadership of Steve Jobs, when he returned to Apple.
  • The monochrome Apple logo replaced the earlier rainbow-coloured logo, which had been in use since 1977.

Additional Information:

  • The change to a simple, single-colour logo reflected Apple’s new minimalist design philosophy.
  • This version of the logo was first used with the launch of the iMac G3 in 1998.
  • The monochrome logo remains the official Apple logo to this day, appearing in various colours depending on product and packaging design.

question:
From the given options, select the developer of ‘PARAM 10000’, a supercomputer of Indian origin.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 08/02/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The supercomputer PARAM 10000 was developed by C-DAC Pune (Centre for Development of Advanced Computing).
  • It was launched in 1998 as a part of India’s National Supercomputing Mission.
  • PARAM 10000 was a significant upgrade from the earlier PARAM 8000, and it placed India among the top countries in supercomputing technology at the time.

Additional Information:

  • PARAM 10000 had a computing speed of 100 Gigaflops (billion floating-point operations per second).
  • It was based on parallel computing architecture and was entirely indigenously developed.
  • C-DAC is an R&D organisation under the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology, Government of India.

question:
Who invented HTML in 1990?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 22/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is Tim Berners-Lee, who invented HTML (HyperText Markup Language) in 1990.
  • HTML is the standard language used to create and structure pages on the World Wide Web.
  • Tim Berners-Lee also invented the World Wide Web itself while working at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research.

Additional Information:

  • HTML allows the creation of links, headings, paragraphs, images, and formatting within a web page.
  • Tim Berners-Lee also developed HTTP and the first web browser, WorldWideWeb.
  • He is often referred to as the father of the web.

question:
Who was one of the founders of American computer Sun Microsystems later acquired by Oracle?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 20/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is Vinod Khosla, who was one of the co-founders of Sun Microsystems, an American computer company.
  • Sun Microsystems was founded in 1982 by Vinod Khosla, Andy Bechtolsheim, Bill Joy, and Scott McNealy.
  • The company became well known for its innovations in network computing, UNIX-based systems, and the development of the Java programming language.

Additional Information:

  • Sun Microsystems was acquired by Oracle Corporation in 2010.
  • Vinod Khosla is an Indian-American entrepreneur and later founded Khosla Ventures, a leading venture capital firm.
  • Other options:
    • Satya Nadella – CEO of Microsoft.
    • Sabeer Bhatia – Co-founder of Hotmail.
    • Sundar Pichai – CEO of Alphabet Inc. (Google's parent company).

question:
Who among the following is not related to Apple in. as its co-founder?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 04/03/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Mark Zuckerberg, who is not related to Apple Inc. as a co-founder.
  • Apple Inc. was founded in 1976 by three individuals:
    • Steve Jobs
    • Steve Wozniak
    • Ronald Wayne
  • Mark Zuckerberg is the co-founder and CEO of Facebook, which was launched in 2004, and has no association with the founding of Apple.

Additional Information:

  • Ronald Wayne sold his share in Apple just 12 days after co-founding it.
  • Steve Wozniak was the technical brain behind the first Apple computer, while Steve Jobs handled product vision and marketing.
  • Apple Inc. is now one of the most valuable technology companies in the world.

question:
Who is considered to be the Father of Modern Computers?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 01/02/20221 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Alan Turing, who is widely regarded as the Father of Modern Computers.
  • Alan Turing was a British mathematician, logician, and computer scientist who laid the foundational concepts of algorithm, computation, and machine logic.
  • His concept of the Turing Machine (1936) became the theoretical basis for all modern computers.

Additional Information:

  • During World War II, Turing played a vital role in breaking the Nazi Enigma code, significantly aiding the Allied victory.
  • Although Charles Babbage is known as the Father of the Computer (for inventing the Analytical Engine), Turing’s work is credited with establishing the principles of modern computing.
  • Other options:
    • Gordon E. Moore – Known for Moore's Law related to chip processing power.
    • James Gosling – Creator of the Java programming language.

question:
The first mechanical computer designed by Charles Babbage was called?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 21/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Analytical Engine.
  • Charles Babbage designed the first mechanical computer known as the Analytical Engine in the 1830s.
  • It was a general-purpose computing machine and considered the first concept of a modern computer.

Additional Information:

  • The Analytical Engine had essential components of a modern computer: an arithmetic logic unit (ALU), control flow via loops and conditionals, and memory.
  • Although it was never completed during Babbage’s lifetime, the design influenced future computer development.
  • Other options:
    • Processor – Refers to a component of modern computers.
    • Calculator – Performs only arithmetic functions, not general-purpose computing.
    • Abacus – An ancient manual calculating device, not a computer.

question:
If Bill Gates had his way, by what name was Windows OS planned to be released?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 10/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Interface Manager.
  • Before its release as Microsoft Windows, the original internal name for the operating system was Interface Manager.
  • Bill Gates and his team used this name because it referred to the system’s ability to manage graphical interface elements like windows, menus, and scrollbars.

Additional Information:

  • The name “Windows” was later chosen by Microsoft marketing because it was more intuitive and descriptive for users.
  • Windows 1.0 was officially released on 20 November 1985.
  • It became one of the most successful and widely used operating systems in computing history.

question:
Who among the following founded Microsoft together with Paul Allen in the year 1975.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 03/04/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Bill Gates.
  • Microsoft was founded in 1975 by Bill Gates and Paul Allen.
  • The company was initially established to develop and sell BASIC interpreters for the Altair 8800 microcomputer.

Additional Information:

  • Bill Gates played a major role in turning Microsoft into the world’s largest software company.
  • Microsoft is best known for products like Windows OS, MS Office, and various enterprise solutions.
  • Other options:
    • Stephen Hawking – Renowned physicist, not associated with Microsoft.
    • Larry Wall – Creator of the Perl programming language.
    • Mark Zuckerberg – Co-founder of Facebook.

question:
Microsoft Corporation was established in the year 1975 __________ ?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/07/2021 (Shift-II)
option_1: Bellevuess, Washington, United States of America.
option_2: Cupertino, California, United States of America.
option_3: Albuquerque, New Mexico, United States of America.
solution:
• Microsoft Corporation was founded in 1975 by Bill Gates and Paul Allen.
  • It was originally established in Albuquerque, New Mexico, USA, to develop software for the Altair 8800 microcomputer.
  • At the time, the company developed and sold a version of the BASIC programming language.

Additional Information:

  • Microsoft later moved its headquarters to Redmond, Washington, in 1986.
  • The initial office in Albuquerque was chosen because MITS, the maker of the Altair 8800, was based there.
  • Options like Cupertino are linked with Apple Inc., not Microsoft.

question:
‘Pen Drive’ was invented by IBM in the year ___________ .

RRB NTPC Stage-I 23/07/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) 1998.
  • The Pen Drive, also known as a USB flash drive, was invented in 1998.
  • It was developed jointly by IBM and M-Systems (an Israeli company), with IBM being the first to introduce it commercially.

Additional Information:

  • The pen drive revolutionised data storage by replacing floppy disks and CDs.
  • It uses flash memory and connects through the USB (Universal Serial Bus) interface.
  • IBM marketed the first USB flash drive as the DiskOnKey.

question:
ENIAC, the first general-purpose electronic computer, stands for:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 07/04/2021 (Shift-II)
option_1: Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer
option_2: Electronic Numerical Integrated Automatic Computer
option_3: Electronic Network Integrated Analytical Computer
option_4: Electronic Network Interactive analytic Computer
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer.
  • ENIAC was the world’s first general-purpose fully electronic digital computer, developed in the United States during World War II.
  • It was designed and built by John Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert at the University of Pennsylvania, and completed in 1945.

Additional Information:

  • ENIAC could perform 5,000 additions or subtractions per second, and was programmable to handle different kinds of calculations.
  • It used vacuum tubes, weighed about 30 tons, and consumed large amounts of electricity.
  • It marked the beginning of the first generation of computers.

question:
The name of the 1st electronic digital computer of the world is:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 01/04/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) ENIAC.
  • ENIAC stands for Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer.
  • It was the first fully electronic general-purpose digital computer in the world, developed in the United States.

Additional Information:

  • ENIAC was built by John Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert at the University of Pennsylvania.
  • It was completed in 1945 and became operational in 1946.
  • Other options:
    • PROLOG – A programming language, not a computer.
    • PARAM – India’s series of supercomputers, developed later.
    • UNIVAC – The first commercial computer, but not the first electronic digital one.

question:
What was the first computer created by JW Mauchly and J Presper Eckert with NO mechanical parts?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 06/04/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) ENIAC.
  • ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer) was the first electronic digital computer built without any mechanical parts, using vacuum tubes for processing and storage.
  • It was developed by John W. Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert at the University of Pennsylvania and completed in 1945.

Additional Information:

  • Unlike earlier computers like Mark I or Mark II, which had electromechanical components, ENIAC was fully electronic.
  • ENIAC used about 18,000 vacuum tubes, weighed 30 tons, and could perform 5,000 additions per second.
  • This made it significantly faster and more powerful than its mechanical predecessors.

question:
Who among the following is known as the ‘Father of Indian Supercomputers’?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 22/02/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Vijay Pandurang Bhatkar.
  • Dr. Vijay Bhatkar is widely known as the ‘Father of Indian Supercomputers’ for leading the development of India’s first indigenous supercomputer PARAM 8000.
  • He was the founding director of C-DAC (Centre for Development of Advanced Computing), which played a crucial role in India's supercomputing mission.

Additional Information:

  • PARAM 8000 was launched in 1991, marking India's entry into the field of high-performance computing.
  • Dr. Bhatkar has received several honours, including the Padma Bhushan and Padma Shri awards.
  • Other options:
    • Jayant Narlikar – Astrophysicist.
    • RA Mashelkar – Renowned scientist in chemical and biological sciences.
    • Nandan Nilekani – Co-founder of Infosys and architect of Aadhaar.

question:
An integrated circuit is commonly known as:

RRB NTPC Stage-I 30/01/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Chip.
  • An Integrated Circuit (IC) is a small electronic device made of semiconductor material that contains many tiny components like transistors, resistors, and capacitors embedded into a single unit.
  • It is commonly called a chip because of its small size and flat rectangular shape.

Additional Information:

  • ICs are used in almost all electronic devices today — from computers and smartphones to cars and medical devices.
  • They help perform various functions such as processing, amplification, switching, and memory storage.
  • Other options:
    • Resistor – Controls current in a circuit.
    • Transistor – Used for amplification and switching but is just one component inside an IC.
    • Plate – Not a component used in modern electronics in this context.

question:
Who among the following is one of the founders of Google?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 17/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Larry Page.
  • Larry Page, along with Sergey Brin, co-founded Google in 1998 while they were Ph.D. students at Stanford University.
  • Google began as a research project and evolved into the world’s most popular search engine.

Additional Information:

  • Larry Page also served as the CEO of Google and later of its parent company Alphabet Inc..
  • Other options:
    • Jerry Yang – Co-founder of Yahoo.
    • Jan Koum – Co-founder of WhatsApp.
    • Mark Zuckerberg – Co-founder and CEO of Facebook.

question:
In which generation were computer vacuum based and costly?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 12/01/2021 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) First generation.
  • First-generation computers (1940s–1950s) used vacuum tubes for circuitry and magnetic drums for memory.
  • These computers were very large, expensive, and produced a lot of heat, making them inefficient compared to later generations.

Additional Information:

  • Vacuum tubes were the main technology used for processing.
  • Programming was done using machine language (binary code).
  • Examples of first-generation computers include ENIAC, EDVAC, and UNIVAC I.
  • Later generations used transistors, integrated circuits, and microprocessors, which were more efficient and less costly.

question:
Which of the following is not a series of the supercomputer PARAM that was developed by Indian scientists?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 08/02/2021 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The PARAM series is a line of Indian supercomputers developed by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC).
  • The first machine in the series was PARAM 8000, launched in 1991.
  • Other well-known supercomputers in this series include PARAM 8600, PARAM Padma, PARAM Yuva, PARAM Brahma, etc.
  • PARAM MITRA is not a part of the official PARAM series developed by Indian scientists. It is a fabricated or non-existent name in the context of PARAM supercomputers.

Additional Information:

  • PARAM stands for "Parallel Machine".
  • PARAM 8000 had a peak performance of 1 GFLOPS.
  • India developed PARAM 8000 after denial of a Cray supercomputer by the US, marking a major leap in self-reliant computing power.

question:
Which of the following does the work of linking all ATMs in India?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 02/02/2021 (Shift-I)
option_1: National Institute of Banking and Management
option_2: National Payments Corporation of India
option_3: Reserve Bank of India
option_4: Securities and Exchange Board of India
solution:
• The organisation responsible for linking all ATMs in India is the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI).
  • NPCI manages the National Financial Switch (NFS), which connects all ATM networks in the country and enables interoperability among different banks' ATMs.
  • This allows customers of one bank to use the ATMs of other banks across India.

Additional Information:

  • NPCI was established in 2008 under the guidance of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and Indian Banks’ Association (IBA).
  • Other major products operated by NPCI include UPI, RuPay, IMPS, BHIM, AePS, etc.
  • NFS, developed by IDRBT and later taken over by NPCI, handles millions of ATM transactions every day.

question:
In a computer system which does not require any storage devices known as-

RRB NTPC Stage-I 27/04/2016 (Shift-I)
solution:
• A computer system that does not require any storage device is called an Analog computer.
  • Analog computers process continuous data and are generally used for scientific and engineering calculations, like in simulations or measurements.
  • Unlike digital computers, they do not store data in memory or storage units; instead, they process signals in real-time.

Additional Information:

  • Digital computers use binary (0s and 1s) and need storage devices like RAM, hard drives.
  • Hybrid computers combine features of both analog and digital computers.
  • Third generation computers (1964–1971) used integrated circuits (ICs) and had storage components.

question:
Till year 2015 _________ which generation computer production has occurred.

RRB NTPC Stage-I 26/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Till the year 2015, computer production had reached the 5th Generation.
  • Fifth Generation Computers are based on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and supercomputing technologies.
  • These computers are capable of natural language processing, decision-making, learning, and parallel processing.

Additional Information:

  • 1st Generation (1940–1956): Vacuum tubes, very large and slow.
  • 2nd Generation (1956–1963): Transistors replaced vacuum tubes.
  • 3rd Generation (1964–1971): Used Integrated Circuits (ICs).
  • 4th Generation (1971–present): Based on Microprocessors.
  • 5th Generation (1980–present): Based on AI, still under development in some aspects, but widely in use by 2015.

question:
Which is the first Apple computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 09/04/2016 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The first Apple computer was the Apple I, launched in 1976.
  • It was designed and hand-built by Steve Wozniak, and marketed by Steve Jobs.
  • Apple I was a single-board computer, and unlike modern computers, it came without a keyboard, monitor, or case — users had to attach these separately.

Additional Information:

  • Only about 200 units of Apple I were produced.
  • It was sold for $666.66.
  • It was succeeded by the Apple II in 1977, which became a major commercial success.
  • Macintosh (1984) and Apple Lisa (1983) came much later and were known for introducing graphical user interfaces.

question:
Who is first world programmer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 09/04/2016 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The first world programmer is Ada Lovelace.
  • She was an English mathematician and writer, known for her work on Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine, an early mechanical general-purpose computer.
  • Ada Lovelace is credited with writing the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine, making her the world’s first computer programmer.

Additional Information:

  • Alan Turing was a pioneering computer scientist known for breaking the Enigma code during WWII and for the Turing machine concept.
  • Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989.
  • Steve Wozniak co-founded Apple and designed the Apple I and II computers, but was not the first programmer.

question:
In which generation of computer mechanical language has been used?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 12/04/2016 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Mechanical language refers to the machine language, which consists of binary code (0s and 1s) directly understood by the hardware.
  • This type of language was used in the First Generation of computers (1940–1956).
  • These computers operated using vacuum tubes and programming was done in machine-level language, which is the most basic form of language a computer can understand.

Additional Information:

  • Second Generation (1956–1963): Used transistors and introduced assembly language.
  • Third Generation (1964–1971): Used Integrated Circuits (ICs) and allowed high-level languages like FORTRAN, COBOL.
  • Fourth Generation (1971–present): Based on microprocessors; advanced programming languages and operating systems were used.

question:
Which of the following is India’s fastest and first petaflops super computer which is inaugurated in Indian institutes of Tropical Meteorology in Pune?

RRB Group-D 08/10/2018 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Pratyush is India’s fastest and first multi-petaflops supercomputer specifically dedicated to weather and climate research.
  • It was inaugurated at the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM), Pune in January 2018.
  • The system has a peak performance of 8 petaflops, making it one of the fastest in India and among the top in the world for meteorology-related computations.

Additional Information:

  • “Pratyush” is used for monsoon prediction, extreme weather forecasting, cyclones, and other climate research purposes.
  • Along with Mihir, another similar supercomputer installed at NCMRWF, Noida, it helps improve India’s weather forecast accuracy.
  • The supercomputer was developed by the Ministry of Earth Sciences (MoES) under the High Performance Computing (HPC) programme.

question:
Who discovered the mouse of computer?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 16/04/2016 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The computer mouse was invented by Douglas Engelbart in the 1960s.
  • He developed the first prototype in 1964 at the Stanford Research Institute.
  • The device was originally made of wood and had two wheels — it was used to control a cursor on the screen.

Additional Information:

  • Douglas Engelbart demonstrated the mouse publicly during “The Mother of All Demos” in 1968.
  • The term "mouse" was coined because the device resembled a rodent with a tail (the wire).
  • Engelbart’s invention revolutionised the way humans interacted with computers, paving the way for graphical user interfaces (GUIs).

question:
The first pair of headphone in 1910 was developed by-

RRB NTPC Stage-II 18/01/2017 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The first pair of headphones was developed by Nathaniel Baldwin in the year 1910.
  • He built the prototype in his kitchen and sold them to the US Navy, who recognised their potential for communication.
  • Baldwin’s headphones were not initially a commercial success, but they laid the foundation for future audio devices.

Additional Information:

  • Nathaniel Baldwin’s invention amplified sound without electricity and was based on sound wave principles.
  • Despite inventing such a breakthrough device, Baldwin never patented his headphones, which limited his personal financial gain.
  • Today’s modern headphones trace their origin back to Baldwin’s design.

question:
What is the name of tablet computer developed by Database, whom India’s government promoted for a part of E-learning?

RRB NTPC Stage-I 04/04/2016 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The tablet computer developed by DataWind and promoted by the Government of India for e-learning purposes was named Aakash.
  • It was launched as the world’s cheapest tablet, aimed at providing affordable access to technology for students.
  • The initiative was a part of the National Mission on Education through ICT (NMEICT) under the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD).

Additional Information:

  • The Aakash tablet featured basic hardware and ran on an Android operating system.
  • It was initially priced around Rs. 1,500 to Rs. 2,500, heavily subsidised by the government.
  • Despite facing production and quality challenges, it represented a significant step in digital inclusion and e-learning in India.

question:
What is the context of word “Digitalization”?

RRB SSE 21/12/2014
option_1: For changing analog signal into digital signal
option_2: For changing digital signal into analog signal
option_3: Uses of analog form of electricity
option_4: A form of physical quantities
solution:
• The word “Digitalization” refers to the conversion of information or signals from analog form into digital form.
  • In technical terms, it involves converting continuous signals (analog) into discrete numerical data (digital) that can be processed by computers.
  • This process allows for efficient storage, processing, and transmission of data in digital devices.

Additional Information:

  • Digitalisation is crucial in areas like telecommunications, multimedia, electronics, and computing.
  • Common examples include converting voice in phones to digital signals, or scanning documents into digital format.
  • It is different from Digitisation, which refers to converting physical data (like paper documents) into digital files.
